   Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L  ALL NORMAL , LDH:318 IU/L   TRENDING DOWN ,
   Ca++:8.0 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:2.7 mg/dL
   Fluid analysis / Other labs: Hapto 418, 430
   B12 and folate normal
   Transferrin and TIBC are low
   Ferritin is normal
   Iron is low 11
   Imaging: CXR this am
   [**12-25**] Abdomen plain film
   There is a nonspecific distribution of bowel gas pattern with no
   evidence of
   obstruction. There is minimal distention of the ascending colon but
   there is
   gas in the transverse, descending colon and rectum. Phleboliths are
   seen in the pelvis. Mild degenerative changes are in the lumbar spine.
   [**12-25**] abd u/s wet read
   No ascites
   Adenomyomatosis in GB
   Main portal vein patent.
   Microbiology: DFA positive for Influenza A
   BCx negative to date x2 and UCx negative to date
   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   Assessment and Plan:
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A
    1) Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely due to an underlying
   pulmonary process: bacterial community Acquired PNA, influenza or
   possibly PCP given his HIV.  PCP unlikely due to stable cd4 count and
   otherwise good HAART compliance, however, pt was started on Bactrim
   yesterday for empiric treatment of PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] Continue Vanc, Ceftriaxone, Azithro x5days for CAP
   - Continue Bactrim empirically. As we are empirically treating him for
   PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] will also start Prednisone 40mg PO bid.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID
   - Now that he is intubated, will do bronch and look for PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **]
   pt has already started empiric Bactrim.
   - Will watch him through today and try to wean down FiO2 and PEEP as
   tolerated
   - Daily RSBI and SBT's
   - Likely need to Tx underlying cause (PNA, influenza)
   2) Abdominal pain: Pt was complaining of abdominal pain before he was
   intubated. Lipase is mildly elevated and trending down, could be mild
   pancreatitis vs HIV meds.
   - Given elevated lipases, will stop the Propofol and start Fentanyl
   Versed instead
   - F/u imaging studies
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess pancreatitis
   - Continue aggressive BM regimen
   - Trend LFT's
   3) Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restart HAART when reliably taking POs
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now. Will get Nutrition
   consult for initiation of TF
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   Communication: Patient & Sister [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11689**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute pneumonia, and influenza A. He has a history of abdominal pain, and his laboratory results show mild elevation of lipase, which could be indicative of mild pancreatitis or HIV medication side effects.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.6Â°F, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 97/54 mmHg. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a FiO2 of 60% and PEEP of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count of 8.1, trending down
* Hct of 32.5, trending down
* Plt of 245, stable
* Cr of 1.3, trending down
* TCO2 of 35, trending down
* Glucose of 78, trending down
* Lipase of 148, trending down
* Amylase of 148, normal
* Lactic Acid of 1.0 mmol/L, normal
* LDH of 318 IU/L, trending down
* Ca++ of 8.0 mg/dL, normal
* Mg++ of 2.3 mg/dL, normal
* PO4 of 2.7 mg/dL, normal

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: bilateral infiltrates consistent with pneumonia
* Abdomen plain film: nonspecific distribution of bowel gas pattern with no evidence of obstruction
* Abd u/s: no ascites, adenomyomatosis in GB, main portal vein patent

The patient's microbiology results show:

* DFA positive for Influenza A
* BCx negative to date x2 and UCx negative to date

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Continue Vanc, Ceftriaxone, and Azithro for 5 days for CAP
* Continue Bactrim empirically for PCP
* Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID for influenza
* Daily RSBI and SBT's
* Likely need to Tx underlying cause (PNA, influenza)
* Abdominal pain: stop Propofol and start Fentanyl Versed, consider CT abdomen to assess pancreatitis
* Acute Renal Failure: trend Cr, Foley catheter to monitor UOP
* Anemia: iron studies, type and screen, trend Hct's
* HIV: restart HAART when reliably taking POs
* DM2: Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
* Hyperlipidemia: hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver dysfunction

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: further deterioration of lung function, need for increased ventilatory support
* Pneumonia: progression to sepsis, need for broader antibiotic coverage
* Pancreatitis: further deterioration of pancreatic function, need for surgical intervention
* Acute Renal Failure: progression to chronic kidney disease, need for dialysis
* Anemia: worsening of anemia, need for blood transfusions
* HIV: progression to AIDS, need for antiretroviral therapy
* DM2: progression to diabetic ketoacidosis, need for insulin therapy
* Hyperlipidemia: progression to pancreatitis, need for lipid-lowering therapy

The patient's treatment plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, antibiotic therapy, and close monitoring of his laboratory results and vital signs.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on invasive ventilation, which increases the risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the underlying cause of hypoxia is not addressed.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has radiographic evidence of pneumonia and a positive DFA for Influenza A, which increases the risk of pneumonia progression and potential complications such as ARDS.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase is mildly elevated and trending down, which could be indicative of mild pancreatitis. If left untreated, pancreatitis can lead to severe complications, including necrosis and sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine has normalized, but it is essential to continue monitoring for signs of acute kidney injury, particularly in the setting of sepsis and hypovolemia.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline, and his MCV is 80, which is concerning for iron deficiency anemia. If left untreated, anemia can exacerbate the patient's underlying condition and increase the risk of complications.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient is taking Atorvastatin, which should be held until liver function is normalized to avoid exacerbating liver dysfunction.
7. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV is not well controlled, and there is a risk of HIV-related complications, such as opportunistic infections, if not managed promptly.
8. Sepsis: The patient's fever and positive DFA for Influenza A increase the risk of sepsis, particularly if not managed promptly and effectively.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal pain and elevated lipase levels increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if pancreatitis is left untreated.
10. Cardiac complications: The patient's underlying cardiovascular condition increases the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, in the setting of sepsis and hypovolemia.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's progress and addressing these potential complications promptly to prevent worsening of their condition and improve their outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old man with HIV and Hepatitis B who presented with respiratory failure, fever, cough, dyspnea, and hypoxemia. He was intubated overnight for respiratory distress and diagnosed with H1N1. The patient has a history of HIV with a viral load of 558 and CD4 count of 323. He discontinued his HAART medication a few days prior to admission. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, and his vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 101.6Â°F, heart rate of 65 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/55 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already intubated and on invasive ventilation, and there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration, particularly if there is a delay in treating underlying conditions such as pneumonia.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's symptoms and radiological findings suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status and increase the risk of complications.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has improved, but there is still a risk of further renal deterioration, particularly if he is not adequately hydrated or if there is a delay in treating underlying conditions.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.8 g/dL, which is below normal. There is a risk of further anemia if he is not adequately transfused or if there is a delay in treating underlying conditions.
5. Infection: The patient's blood and urine cultures are negative, but there is still a risk of infection, particularly if he is not adequately treated with antibiotics.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is impaired, and there is a risk of further neurological deterioration, particularly if he is not adequately treated for his underlying conditions.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's abdominal pain and nausea suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, which could worsen his overall condition.
8. DVT and PE: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), particularly if he is not adequately anticoagulated.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A
   .
   # Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely due to an underlying
   pulmonary process: bacterial community Acquired PNA, influenza or
   possibly PCP given his HIV.  PCP unlikely due to stable cd4 count and
   otherwise good HAART compliance, however, pt was started on Bactrim
   yesterday for empiric treatment of PCP.
   [**Name Initial (NameIs) **] Continue Vanc, Ceftriaxone, Azithro x5days for CAP
   - Continue Bactrim empirically. As we are empirically treating him for
   PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] will also start Prednisone 40mg PO bid.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID
   - Will watch him through today and try to wean down FiO2 and PEEP as
   tolerated
   - Daily RSBI and SBT's
   2) Abdominal pain: Pt was complaining of abdominal pain before he was
   intubated. Lipase is mildly elevated and trending down, could be mild
   pancreatitis vs HIV meds.
   - Given elevated lipases, will stop the Propofol and start Fentanyl
   Versed instead
   - F/u imaging studies
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess pancreatitis
   - Continue aggressive BM regimen
   - Trend LFT's
   .
   3) Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restart HAART when reliably taking POs
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now. Will get Nutrition
   consult for initiation of TF
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   Communication: Patient & Sister [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11689**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, with desaturation and the need for increased PEEP. This may lead to further respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has multifocal pneumonia, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and increased mortality.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase levels are mildly elevated, and he is experiencing abdominal pain. This may indicate mild pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as necrosis, abscesses, and sepsis.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are normal, but there is a risk of acute renal failure due to the underlying illness and potential nephrotoxic medications.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline, and there is concern for iron deficiency anemia. This may lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased immune function.
6. HIV-related complications: The patient has HIV, which can lead to opportunistic infections, such as PCP, and other complications such as lymphoma and neurological disorders.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease and other complications.
8. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may be due to pancreatitis, HIV medications, or other underlying causes, which can lead to complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, and sepsis.
9. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to the underlying illness, pneumonia, and potential bacterial infections.
10. Multi-organ failure: The patient's underlying illness and potential complications may lead to multi-organ failure, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continued treatment for pneumonia, including antibiotics and steroids.
2. Management of abdominal pain, including stopping propofol and starting fentanyl and versed.
3. Monitoring of kidney function and potential acute renal failure.
4. Treatment of anemia, including iron studies and type and screen.
5. Restarting HAART when the patient is reliably taking PO medications.
6. Monitoring of blood sugars and potential hyperglycemia.
7. Holding atorvastatin due to potential liver dysfunction.
8. Nutrition consult for initiation of tube feeds.
9. Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcer prophylaxis.
10. Regular monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to detect potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of flu and PNA. He was found to have worsening of retrocardiac left lung base consolidation, and a diagnosis of multifocal pneumonia was made. He was started on empiric treatment for PCP, CAP, and influenza A. The patient is currently intubated and on ventilator support, with a FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. He is also receiving antibiotics, steroids, and antiviral medication.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia and worsening of lung consolidation may lead to respiratory failure, which could require further interventions such as increasing PEEP or using non-invasive ventilation.
2. Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated lipase levels and abdominal pain may indicate mild pancreatitis, which could worsen if not managed properly.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate acute renal failure, which could require further management and monitoring.
4. Anemia: The patient's low Hct and MCV may indicate iron deficiency anemia, which could require further evaluation and treatment.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, but may require restarting HAART when he is able to take PO medications.
6. DM2: The patient's blood sugars appear well-controlled, but may require further monitoring and management.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's elevated lipase levels may indicate hyperlipidemia, which could require further evaluation and treatment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric treatment for PCP, CAP, and influenza A, and monitor the patient's response to treatment.
2. Wean the patient off ventilator support as tolerated, and consider using non-invasive ventilation if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and lipase levels to rule out pancreatitis.
4. Trend the patient's creatinine levels to monitor for acute renal failure.
5. Evaluate the patient's anemia and consider further treatment if necessary.
6. Restart HAART when the patient is able to take PO medications.
7. Monitor the patient's blood sugars and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Hold Atorvastatin until liver dysfunction is ruled out.
9. Consider restarting tube feeds and replete electrolytes as necessary.

* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O. His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.39, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 45 mmHg, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 95 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds and peripheral pulses
* Respiratory: Bronchial breath sounds in the left base
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema (1+) and left lower extremity edema (1+)
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 5.2 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 254 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 26 mEq/L
* Sodium: 140 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.9 mEq/L
* Glucose: 114 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes HIV, hypertension, diabetes mellitus (DM), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is currently receiving treatment for influenza PNA with Tamiflu and is awaiting BAL results for PCP.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to influenza PNA or PCP
* Sepsis or septic shock due to pneumonia or other underlying infections
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to inflammation or injury to the lungs
* Pneumothorax or hemothorax due to mechanical ventilation
* Cardiac arrhythmias or myocardial infarction due to underlying cardiovascular disease
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury due to sepsis or underlying kidney disease
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or pancreatitis due to underlying gastrointestinal disease
* Neurological complications such as seizures or stroke due to sepsis or underlying neurological disease.

Given the patient's critical condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and initiate appropriate interventions.

   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic

   .

   pulmonary process: bacterial community Acquired PNA, influenza or

   otherwise good HAART compliance, however, pt was started on Bactrim and

   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency

   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen

   .

   at this time due to illness.
   - restart HAART when reliably taking POs
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute, due to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and influenza A. The patient's hypoxia is likely caused by an underlying pulmonary process, and PCP is unlikely due to stable CD4 count and good HAART compliance.

The patient has several medical conditions and complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which is being treated with mechanical ventilation and antibiotics.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient was complaining of abdominal pain before intubation, and lipase levels are mildly elevated, which could be due to mild pancreatitis or HIV medications.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels were elevated on admission, but have since normalized.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin levels are lower than baseline, and his MCV is 80, which could be due to iron deficiency anemia.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, but not on HAART at this time due to illness.
6. DM2: The patient's blood sugars appear well-controlled.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient is being held on Atorvastatin due to liver dysfunction.

The patient is receiving several medications, including:

* Vanc (vancomycin) for CAP
* Ceftriaxone for CAP
* Azithro for CAP
* Bactrim for empiric treatment of PCP
* Prednisone for empiric treatment of PCP
* Oseltamivir for influenza A
* Fentanyl and Versed for pain management
* Prophylactic heparin for DVT prevention
* Omeprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7Â°C, heart rate of 76 bpm, blood pressure of 100/51 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient's laboratory results show mild elevation of lipase levels, and his WBC count is within normal limits.

The patient's plan is to continue Vanc, Ceftriaxone, and Azithro for CAP, and to continue empiric treatment for PCP. The patient will also receive Oseltamivir for influenza A. The patient's abdominal pain is being managed with fentanyl and Versed, and his anemia is being monitored. The patient's HIV is being managed with HAART, and his DM2 is being managed with insulin. The patient's hyperlipidemia is being held due to liver dysfunction.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure could worsen, leading to further hypoxia and respiratory distress.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain could worsen, leading to further elevation of lipase levels and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels could worsen, leading to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further blood loss and potentially life-threatening complications.
* HIV: The patient's HIV could worsen, leading to further immune suppression and potentially life-threatening complications.
* DM2: The patient's DM2 could worsen, leading to further blood sugar control issues and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, who developed severe influenza with possible overlying ARDS and/or overlying pneumonia. He was intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, and he may be extubated as early as tomorrow. He is several liters positive over his length of stay and would likely benefit from diuresis. The plan is to start diuresis with lasix boluses with a goal of negative 1-2 liters.

The patient has mild abdominal pain, which is likely related to constipation. His lipase is mildly elevated, trending down, and he does not have epigastric pain. An abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct obstruction, and KUB had no evidence of obstruction. The plan is to try a tap-water enema and increase the frequency of miralax.

The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent evidence of bleeding, and his MCV is 80, which raises concern for iron deficiency anemia. Hemolysis is unlikely but not impossible. The plan is to perform iron studies, type and screen, and trend Hct's.

The patient has acute renal failure on admission, but his Cr has now normalized. The plan is to trend Cr and monitor UOP with a Foley catheter.

The patient has anemia, which is likely related to chronic disease. The plan is to restart HAART when reliably taking Pos and try to contact the outpatient infectious disease doctor.

The patient has diabetes mellitus type 2, and his blood sugars appear well controlled. The plan is to continue Q6 ISS and no standing insulin.

The patient has hyperlipidemia, and the plan is to hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still experience respiratory failure if his pneumonia worsens or if he develops ARDS.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient's mild abdominal pain may worsen if he develops a bowel obstruction or if his constipation persists.
3. Anemia: The patient's iron deficiency anemia may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment with HAART.
6. Diabetes mellitus type 2: The patient's diabetes mellitus type 2 may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen if he does not receive adequate treatment.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue monitoring his respiratory status, abdominal pain, anemia, acute renal failure, HIV, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hyperlipidemia.

   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A

The patient's medical history includes HIV, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hyperlipidemia. The patient is currently receiving antiretroviral therapy and is being treated for pneumonia and acute respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already experiencing acute respiratory failure, which can worsen if not properly managed.

3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is slightly elevated, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is lower than baseline, which may indicate iron deficiency anemia or hemolysis.

6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood sugar levels are not well controlled, which can increase the risk of diabetic complications.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but slight imbalances can occur, which can affect the patient's overall condition.

In summary, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART who was admitted to the ICU with severe influenza, pneumonia, and acute respiratory failure. The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic systems to prevent potential complications.

   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Patient has severe influenza with possible
   overlying ARDS and/or overlying pneumonia.  PCP culture negative, no
   longer giving Bactrim and prednisone.  His respiratory status is
   improving and he could potentially be extubated as early as tomorrow.
   He would likely benefit from diuresis, as he is several liters positive

   biliary duct obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.

   constipation for several days. Lipase is mildly elevated, trending down
   and he does not have epigastric pain.  His abdominal U/S showed no
   biliary duct obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.
   Likely he just needs a more aggressive bowel regimen.
   - Follow-up final read of KUB
   - Decrease frequency of miralax
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute, and abdominal pain. He has a history of pneumonia, influenza A, and constipation. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a recent increase in his respiratory support due to desaturation and elevated respiratory system compliance index (RSBI). He has been experiencing abdominal pain, constipation, and mild distension. His laboratory results show mild elevations in lipase and amylase, with a normal white blood cell count and hemoglobin. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his blood glucose levels appear well-controlled.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still require continued mechanical ventilation and respiratory support. He may benefit from diuresis to reduce his fluid overload and improve his respiratory function.
2. Abdominal Pain: The patient's abdominal pain is likely related to constipation, which may require more aggressive bowel regimen and monitoring of his lipase and amylase levels.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels have normalized, but he may still require close monitoring of his kidney function and fluid status.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to iron deficiency, which may require iron supplements and monitoring of his hemoglobin levels.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, but he may require restarting his HAART regimen once his illness resolves.
6. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2: The patient's blood glucose levels appear well-controlled, but he may require continued monitoring and adjustments to his insulin regimen.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require adjustments to his lipid-lowering therapy, including holding his atorvastatin and re-evaluating his liver function.

Overall, the patient's condition appears stable, but he requires continued close monitoring and management of his respiratory, abdominal, and metabolic status to prevent potential complications.

   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, new hypoxia, radiographic evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A. He has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute, and is currently on mechanical ventilation. He also has abdominal pain, constipation, and acute renal failure. His laboratory results show mild elevation in lipase, trending down, and his abdominal ultrasound and KUB have shown no evidence of obstruction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, and he may be extubated as early as tomorrow. However, there is still a risk of respiratory complications, such as ARDS, pneumonia, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is likely related to constipation, but there is a risk of complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, and sepsis.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine has normalized, but there is still a risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin is lower than baseline, and there is a risk of iron deficiency anemia, hemolysis, and chronic disease.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV is well-controlled, but there is a risk of HIV-related complications, such as opportunistic infections and antiretroviral therapy-related side effects.
6. Diabetes: The patient's blood sugars appear well-controlled, but there is a risk of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's lipase is mildly elevated, and there is a risk of pancreatitis and liver dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue respiratory support and wean FiO2 and PEEP as tolerated.
2. Monitor the patient's abdominal pain and constipation and adjust bowel regimen as needed.
3. Continue diuresis with lasix and monitor for signs of fluid overload.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust fluid management accordingly.
5. Restart HAART and monitor for HIV-related complications.
6. Monitor the patient's blood sugars and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
7. Hold Atorvastatin and monitor for liver dysfunction.
8. Consider placing a PICC line in the future.
9. Monitor the patient's electrolytes and adjust therapy as needed.
10. Consider performing a stool culture and C. difficile toxin assay to rule out infections.

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 572 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 16 cmH2O, and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 91% on 50% FiO2.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's heart rate is 84 beats per minute, blood pressure is 91/64 mmHg, and central venous pressure is not reported. The patient's cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Abdominal status: The patient's abdomen is soft, mildly tender, and mildly distended. The patient is constipated and has had a large stool output with liquid stool.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 4.8-4.9 K/uL, hemoglobin is 11.0-11.1 g/dL, platelet count is 283-324 K/uL, and creatinine is 1.0-1.1 mg/dL. The patient's liver enzymes, including aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), are elevated.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration may lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other respiratory complications.
* Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal distension and constipation may increase the risk of abdominal compartment syndrome, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Infection: The patient's constipation and abdominal pain may be indicative of an underlying infection, such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff), which may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's constipation and abdominal pain may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which may require urgent endoscopy and treatment.
* Septic shock: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate an underlying sepsis, which may lead to septic shock if not promptly treated.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's respiratory, hemodynamic, and abdominal status, as well as laboratory results, and adjust treatment accordingly.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.2Â°C, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 91/64 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 19 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 91%.

The patient's laboratory results show mild elevations in lipase and amylase, which may be related to constipation. His liver function tests are normal, and his kidney function is improving, with a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's abdominal pain is mild and may be related to constipation. His stool is liquid, and he has had a big stool and now it's all liquid. He is being treated with Simethicone and Miralax, and a tap-water enema has been ordered.

The patient's respiratory failure is improving, and he may be extubated as early as tomorrow. He is receiving diuresis with Lasix, and his fluid balance is being monitored.

The patient's HIV is well-controlled, and he is due to restart HAART when reliably taking his medications. His blood sugars are well-controlled, and his hyperlipidemia is being managed with Atorvastatin.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still experience respiratory failure if he does not continue to improve.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may worsen if his constipation is not managed effectively.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is improving, but he may still experience acute renal failure if his kidney function does not continue to improve.
4. Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline, and he may experience anemia if his kidney function does not improve.
5. HIV: The patient's HIV is well-controlled, but he may experience complications related to his HIV if he does not continue to take his medications as directed.
6. DM2: The patient's blood sugars are well-controlled, but he may experience complications related to his diabetes if his blood sugars are not managed effectively.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is being managed with Atorvastatin, but he may experience complications related to his hyperlipidemia if his lipid levels are not managed effectively.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continue diuresis with Lasix to manage fluid overload.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
3. Manage the patient's abdominal pain with Simethicone and Miralax.
4. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid management as needed.

7. Monitor the patient's HIV and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old man with HIV, admitted with Influenza PNA and respiratory failure. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been improving, with his respiratory failure described as "improving, close to extubation, but still mild desaturation with SBT."

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Despite improving, the patient's respiratory failure is still a concern, and there is a risk of desaturation with spontaneous breathing trials (SBT).
2. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain has improved with bowel movement, but there is still a risk of further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
3. Constipation: The patient has been experiencing constipation, which can lead to further complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
4. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's blood glucose levels have been fluctuating, and there is a risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis if not properly managed.
5. HIV-related complications: The patient's HIV status increases his risk of developing opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) or Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disease.
6. Thrombotic complications: The patient is at risk of developing thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), given his critical illness and immobility.
7. Sepsis: The patient's respiratory failure and abdominal pain increase his risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiovascular status is unclear, and there is a risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.

To mitigate these risks, the patient should be closely monitored and managed according to established guidelines for critical care patients with HIV and respiratory failure.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.  This morning he is agitated
   with increasing O2 requirement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Unclear why patient has an increased oxygen
   requirement this morning and we are unable to wean him from the vent.
   He did not do well with diuresis and he is not very fluid up on this
   admission.
   - CT chest to better evaluate his chest process and O2 requirement.
   - repeat blood and sputum cultures.
   - Continue Vanc and Ceftriaxone x7 days; today is day 7.  We will
   continue these abx until we have the chest CT.  If there is signs of
   bacterial pneumonia, we will consider broadening to include pseudomonas
   considering increasing O2.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID.  Today is day 5.  Will continue for 10 day
   course.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT's
   # Abdominal pain: Patient again says that he has abdominal pain and he
   is agitated this morning.  His abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct
   obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.  He is now
   stooling, but given that he is getting a CT scan of his lungs we will
   expand to a CT torso.
   - f/u CT torso.
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;
   lipase trending towards normal now
   - Continue BM regimen, but less aggressive
   .
   # Agitation: patient is difficult to adequately sedate with
   fentanyl/versed but had previously been relatively calm.  Unclear
   whether he has a new process going on or has new delirium.
   - repeat cultures as above.
   - continue with fent/versed for now.  Reassess in PM.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restarted HAART, home regimen
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: Peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future. Place A-line
   today.
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)

   Disposition: Pending clinical improvement/extubation

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, new hypoxia, radiographic evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has an increased oxygen requirement and is unable to be weaned from the ventilator. A CT chest is planned to better evaluate the chest process and oxygen requirement.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient reports abdominal pain, which has resolved with bowel movements. A CT torso is planned to evaluate the abdominal process.
3. Agitation: The patient is agitated and difficult to sedate with fentanyl/versed. Repeat cultures are planned, and reassessment is scheduled.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine has normalized, and a Foley catheter is planned to monitor urine output.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline, and iron studies are planned to evaluate for iron deficiency anemia.
6. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, and HAART has been restarted.
7. DM2: Blood sugars appear well-controlled, and standing insulin has been held.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, ARDS, or other respiratory complications can worsen the patient's condition.
2. Abdominal pain: Gastrointestinal perforation, abscess, or bleeding can occur if the abdominal process is not properly managed.
3. Agitation: Delirium, agitation, or other neuropsychiatric complications can worsen the patient's condition.
4. Acute Renal Failure: Kidney damage or failure can occur if the patient's creatinine continues to rise.
5. Anemia: Iron deficiency anemia can worsen the patient's condition if left untreated.
6. HIV: HIV-related complications, such as opportunistic infections or immune reconstitution syndrome, can occur if the patient's HIV is not properly managed.
7. DM2: Blood sugar control can deteriorate if the patient's insulin regimen is not properly managed.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

   .

   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80

   Access: Peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future. Place A-line

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old male with HIV on HAART, who was admitted with respiratory failure due to severe influenza with possible underlying ARDS and/or pneumonia. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs are stable, but he has mild abdominal pain and constipation. His laboratory results show mild elevation of lipase and amylase, but his liver function tests (LFTs) are trending towards normal. He has anemia, but his hemoglobin level is lower than his baseline without recent evidence of bleeding. His HIV is currently well-controlled, and he is not on HAART at this time due to his illness. He has diabetes mellitus type 2 and hyperlipidemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he may still require mechanical ventilation and close monitoring to prevent further complications.
2. Abdominal pain and constipation: The patient's abdominal pain and constipation may be related to his underlying medical conditions, and close monitoring of his bowel movements and abdominal pain is necessary to prevent further complications.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his underlying medical conditions, and close monitoring of his hemoglobin level and blood count is necessary to prevent further complications.
4. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, but close monitoring of his viral load and CD4 count is necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Diabetes mellitus type 2: The patient's blood sugar levels appear to be well-controlled, but close monitoring of his blood sugar levels and insulin therapy is necessary to prevent further complications.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may be related to his underlying medical conditions, and close monitoring of his lipid levels and cholesterol levels is necessary to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status.
2. Continue to manage the patient's abdominal pain and constipation with aggressive bowel regimen and close monitoring of his bowel movements.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and hemoglobin level, and consider transfusions if necessary.
4. Restart HAART and close monitoring of the patient's viral load and CD4 count.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood sugar levels and insulin therapy.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's lipid levels and cholesterol levels, and consider adjustments to his lipid-lowering therapy as necessary.

Summary:

The patient, a 60-year-old man, is being treated for influenza pneumonia in the ICU. He had an episode of hyperosmolar non-ketotic hyperglycemia (HOTN) overnight, which improved after holding the lasix drip. This morning, he became agitated and more tachypneic, requiring an increase in ventilator settings. He is currently on a CPAP/PSV mode with a PS of 10 cmH2O, RR of 36, and FiO2 of 50%. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6Â°C, heart rate of 94 bpm, and blood pressure of 125/108 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a need for increased ventilator support and a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Hypoxemia: The patient's SpO2 is 90%, which may indicate hypoxemia, especially considering the high FiO2 setting.
3. Influenza pneumonia: The patient's influenza pneumonia may progress, leading to worsening respiratory failure and increased risk of complications.
4. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction and further complications.
5. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may indicate underlying abdominal pathology, which needs to be ruled out with further imaging studies.
6. Sedation: The patient's sedation regimen may need to be adjusted to balance the need for sedation with the risk of respiratory depression.
7. Fluid management: The patient's fluid management may need to be adjusted to prevent fluid overload and worsening respiratory failure.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing secondary infections, particularly pneumonia, due to his underlying condition and immunosuppressive therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue influenza treatment with tamiflu.
2. Obtain a CT chest to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess lung parenchyma.
3. Obtain a CT abdomen to rule out intrabdominal pathology.
4. Continue sedation with versed/fentanyl and adjust as needed.
5. Continue HIV medications.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust fluid management accordingly.
8. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's regimen if there is evidence of infection.

   Microbiology: [**2163-12-30**] 10:50 am SPUTUM      Source: Endotracheal.

        <10 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field.     1+    (<1 per
   1000X FIELD):   BUDDING YEAST WITH PSEUDOHYPHAE.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.  This morning he is agitated
   with increasing O2 requirement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Unclear why patient has an increased oxygen
   requirement this morning and we are unable to wean him from the vent.
   He did not do well with diuresis and he is not very fluid up on this
   admission. CT chest w/ ground glass and not effusions.  Wonder if this
   is his problem is [**Name2 (NI) 11805**] vs pulmonary vasculature
   - f/u repeat blood and sputum cultures. Only (+) for yeast at this
   point.
   - Completed 7/10 days of Vanc and Ceftriaxone.  CT chest shows PNA
   still present.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID.  Today is day 6.  Will continue for 10 day
   course.
   - try to wean PEEP to see if he is PEEP-responsive suggesting a
   parenchymal or mechanical cause of his resp distress
   - if PEEP unable to be weaned, drop esophageal balloon to measure
   pressures because may be higher than assume based on CXR and exam
   - LENI to look for DVT and call radiology to see if there are PE
s on
   imaging even though it is not a CTA
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Patient again says that he has abdominal pain and he
   is agitated this morning.  His abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct
   obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.  He is now
   stooling, but given that he is getting a CT scan of his lungs we will
   expand to a CT torso. No cause of abdominal pain seen on CT scan.
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;
   lipase trending towards normal now
   - Continue BM regimen, but less aggressive
   - Continue to monitor, seems to have stabilized
   .
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: would appear that has metabolic acidosis that is
   compensated, but since on vent could be that had resp acidosis w/
   metabolic compensation and has started to hyperventilate acutely.  An
   acute resp alkalosis on a compensated resp acidosis.
   - Treat resp distress
   .
   # Agitation: patient is difficult to adequately sedate with
   fentanyl/versed but had previously been relatively calm.  Unclear
   whether he has a new process going on or has new delirium.
   - continue with fent/versed for now.
   - add seroquel to see if can wean sedation
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restarted HAART, home regimen
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: Peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future. Place A-line
   today.
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   Communication: Patient & sister [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11689**]

   Assessment and Plan
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.  This morning he is agitated
   with increasing O2 requirement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Unclear why patient has an increased oxygen
   requirement this morning and we are unable to wean him from the vent.
   He did not do well with diuresis and he is not very fluid up on this
   admission. CT chest w/ ground glass and not effusions.  Wonder if this
   is his problem is [**Name2 (NI) 11805**] vs pulmonary vasculature
   - f/u repeat blood and sputum cultures. Only (+) for yeast at this
   point.
   - Completed 7/10 days of Vanc and Ceftriaxone.  CT chest shows PNA
   still present.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID.  Today is day 6.  Will continue for 10 day
   course.
   - try to wean PEEP to see if he is PEEP-responsive suggesting a
   parenchymal or mechanical cause of his resp distress
   - if PEEP unable to be weaned, drop esophageal balloon to measure
   pressures because may be higher than assume based on CXR and exam
   - LENI to look for DVT and call radiology to see if there are PE
s on
   imaging even though it is not a CTA
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Patient again says that he has abdominal pain and he
   is agitated this morning.  His abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct
   obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.  He is now
   stooling, but given that he is getting a CT scan of his lungs we will
   expand to a CT torso. No cause of abdominal pain seen on CT scan.
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;
   lipase trending towards normal now
   - Continue BM regimen, but less aggressive
   - Continue to monitor, seems to have stabilized
   .
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: would appear that has metabolic acidosis that is
   compensated, but since on vent could be that had resp acidosis w/
   metabolic compensation and has started to hyperventilate acutely.  An
   acute resp alkalosis on a compensated resp acidosis.
   - Treat resp distress
   .
   # Agitation: patient is difficult to adequately sedate with
   fentanyl/versed but had previously been relatively calm.  Unclear
   whether he has a new process going on or has new delirium.
   - continue with fent/versed for now.
   - add seroquel to see if can wean sedation
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restarted HAART, home regimen
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: Peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future. Place A-line
   today.

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV, who was admitted to the ICU with ARDS, pneumonia, and influenza A. He has been on mechanical ventilation with increasing oxygen requirement. His chest X-ray shows patchy ground-glass opacity in the left upper lobe, which is nonspecific and could represent an infectious or inflammatory process. He has also been diagnosed with yeast in his sputum, but no evidence of acute intraabdominal process.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9Â°C, heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 114/63 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93%. He is sedated and intubated on a ventilator.

The patient has several medical complications, including respiratory failure, abdominal pain, metabolic alkalosis, agitation, acute renal failure, anemia, HIV, diabetes mellitus type 2, and hyperlipidemia. He is being treated with antibiotics, antivirals, and other medications to manage his conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's increasing oxygen requirement and inability to wean from the ventilator may indicate a worsening of his respiratory failure.
2. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may be related to his underlying conditions, such as pancreatitis or cholecystitis, or it may be a symptom of a new condition.
3. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis may be related to his respiratory acidosis and may require treatment with acidosis.
4. Agitation: The patient's agitation may be related to his underlying conditions, such as sepsis or metabolic disorders, or it may be a symptom of a new condition.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may be related to his underlying conditions, such as sepsis or nephrotoxicity, or it may be a symptom of a new condition.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his underlying conditions, such as chronic disease or hemolysis, or it may be a symptom of a new condition.
7. HIV: The patient's HIV may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.
8. Diabetes mellitus type 2: The patient's diabetes mellitus type 2 may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely.
2. Consider repeating blood and sputum cultures to rule out other potential causes of his infection.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to his treatment regimen if his infection is not responding to current treatment.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal pain and consider repeating imaging studies to rule out other potential causes of his pain.
5. Consider adding acidosis treatment to his regimen if his metabolic alkalosis is not responding to current treatment.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's agitation and consider adding sedation medication if necessary.
7. Consider repeating imaging studies to rule out other potential causes of his acute renal failure.
8. Consider adding iron supplements to his regimen if his anemia is not responding to current treatment.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's HIV and diabetes mellitus type 2 and consider adjusting his treatment regimen as necessary.
10. Consider adding lipid-lowering medication to his regimen if his hyperlipidemia is not responding to current treatment.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's increased oxygen requirement and inability to wean from the ventilator may indicate a worsening respiratory condition.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has radiographic evidence of pneumonia, and the sputum culture is positive for yeast. This may indicate a fungal infection, which could be a complication of the patient's immunocompromised state due to HIV.
3. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is ongoing, and the CT scan did not reveal any cause. The patient's lipase levels are elevated, which may indicate pancreatitis or another pancreatic disorder.
4. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be compensated, but the development of respiratory alkalosis could indicate a worsening condition.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels have normalized, but the patient is still at risk for acute renal failure due to the ongoing respiratory and metabolic conditions.
6. Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline, and the MCV is elevated, suggesting iron deficiency anemia. However, the patient's haptoglobin levels are normal, making hemolysis less likely.
7. HIV: The patient's HIV is currently well-controlled, but the patient's immunocompromised state increases the risk of opportunistic infections.
8. Diabetes mellitus: The patient's blood sugar levels appear well-controlled, but the patient's hyperglycemia may worsen due to the ongoing metabolic conditions.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's lipid levels are elevated, and the patient is at risk for further complications due to the ongoing liver dysfunction.

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.  This morning he is agitated
   with increasing O2 requirement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Unclear why patient has an increased oxygen
   requirement this morning and we are unable to wean him from the vent.
   He did not do well with diuresis and he is not very fluid up on this
   admission. CT chest w/ ground glass and not effusions.
   - f/u repeat blood and sputum cultures. Only (+) for yeast at this
   point.
   - Completed 7 days of Vanc and Ceftriaxone.  CT chest shows PNA still
   present.  Should add cipro and change to cefipime for pseudomonas
   coverage.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID.  Today is day 5.  Will continue for 10 day
   course.
   - Daily RSBI and SBT's
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Patient again says that he has abdominal pain and he
   is agitated this morning.  His abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct
   obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.  He is now
   stooling, but given that he is getting a CT scan of his lungs we will
   expand to a CT torso. No cause of abdominal pain seen on CT scan.
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;
   lipase trending towards normal now
   - Continue BM regimen, but less aggressive
   .
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: would appear that has metabolic acidosis that is
   compensated, but since on vent could be that had resp acidosis w/
   metabolic compensation and has started to hyperventilate acutely.  An
   acute resp alkalosis on a compensated resp acidosis.
   - Treat resp distress
   .
   # Agitation: patient is difficult to adequately sedate with
   fentanyl/versed but had previously been relatively calm.  Unclear
   whether he has a new process going on or has new delirium.
   - repeat cultures as above.
   - continue with fent/versed for now.  Reassess in PM.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restarted HAART, home regimen
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID

Summary:

The patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV, who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and pneumonia. He has been on mechanical ventilation with increasing oxygen requirements and has not been able to be weaned off the vent. His chest CT scan shows patchy ground-glass opacity in the left upper lobe, which is nonspecific and could represent an infectious or inflammatory process. He has also developed abdominal pain, which has been evaluated with ultrasound and CT scan, but no cause has been identified. He has been diagnosed with metabolic alkalosis, agitation, and acute renal failure, and is being treated with fentanyl and versed for sedation. His HIV is well-controlled, but he has developed anemia, which is being evaluated further. He is also being treated for hyperlipidemia and has a history of diabetes and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's increased oxygen requirement and inability to be weaned off the vent suggest a high risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and positive sputum culture for yeast suggest a high risk of sepsis.
3. Abdominal infection: The patient's abdominal pain and lack of clear cause suggest a high risk of abdominal infection.
4. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient's metabolic alkalosis could worsen if not treated, leading to respiratory and cardiovascular complications.
5. Agitation: The patient's agitation could worsen if not treated, leading to increased oxygen requirements and respiratory failure.
6. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure could worsen if not treated, leading to electrolyte imbalances and cardiovascular complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen if not treated, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
8. HIV complications: The patient's HIV could worsen if not treated, leading to opportunistic infections and complications.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could worsen if not treated, leading to cardiovascular complications.
10. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes could worsen if not treated, leading to hyperglycemia and cardiovascular complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation accordingly.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and antivirals as necessary.
3. Evaluate the patient's abdominal pain further to determine the cause and treat accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's metabolic alkalosis and treat accordingly.
5. Continue to treat the patient's agitation with sedatives and analgesics as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's acute renal failure and treat accordingly.
7. Evaluate the patient's anemia further to determine the cause and treat accordingly.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's HIV status and treat accordingly.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperlipidemia and treat accordingly.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's diabetes and treat accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old gentleman with HIV on HAART, who was admitted with new-onset hypoxia, radiographic evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A. He is currently intubated and receiving respiratory support.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9Â°C, heart rate of 91 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 114/63 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 93% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 4.9-7.2 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 34.1-36.3%
* Plt: 324-370 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.0-1.0 mg/dL
* TCO2: 29-35 mmHg
* Glucose: 99-132 mg/dL
* Other lab results: PT/PTT/INR: 13.4/32.5/1.1, ALT/AST: 49/59 IU/L, Alk Phos/T Bili: 84/0.3 IU/L, Amylase/Lipase: 78/64 IU/L, Lactic Acid: 1.5 mmol/L, LDH: 309 IU/L, Ca++: 8.5 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.4 mg/dL, PO4: 4.0 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* CXR: Patchy ground-glass opacity in the left upper lobe of the lung, nonspecific and could represent an infectious or inflammatory process; bibasilar atelectasis is noted without pleural effusion.
* CT chest: Multiple mediastinal lymph nodes that do not meet pathologic size criteria and may simply be reactive lymph nodes; no evidence of acute intraabdominal process.

The patient's microbiology results show:

* Sputum Gram stain: <10 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field; 1+ (<1 per 1000X field): budding yeast with pseudohyphae.
* (+) MRSA screen
* (+) DFA

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: unable to wean from the vent; considering PEEP weaning and esophageal balloon drop to measure pressures.
* Abdominal pain: patient is agitated and complaining of abdominal pain; abdominal U/S and KUB showed no evidence of obstruction; considering CT torso to evaluate for cause of pain.
* Metabolic alkalosis: patient is hyperventilating and has a compensated metabolic acidosis; treating respiratory distress.
* Agitation: patient is difficult to sedate with fentanyl/versed; considering adding seroquel to wean sedation.
* Acute Renal Failure: patient's Cr has normalized; monitoring UOP and trending Cr.
* Anemia: patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent evidence of bleeding; considering iron studies and type and screen.
* HIV: patient's HIV is well-controlled; restarting HAART regimen.
* DM2: patient's blood sugars are well-controlled; monitoring with Q6 ISS.
* Hyperlipidemia: holding Atorvastatin until liver dysfunction is resolved.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: prolonged intubation and ventilation, respiratory muscle weakness, and secondary infections.
* Abdominal pain: bowel obstruction, perforation, or hemorrhage.
* Metabolic alkalosis: respiratory acidosis, cardiac arrhythmias, and muscle weakness.
* Agitation: increased sedation requirements, delirium, and potential for falls or other accidents.
* Acute Renal Failure: progressive kidney damage, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiovascular instability.
* Anemia: worsening anemia, decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, and potential for cardiac complications.
* HIV: opportunistic infections, antiretroviral therapy resistance, and potential for immunosuppression.
* DM2: hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and potential for cardiovascular and kidney complications.
* Hyperlipidemia: liver dysfunction, pancreatitis, and potential for cardiovascular and kidney complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac arrest. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.6Â°F, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 600 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 10 mmHg and a pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) pressure of 15 mmHg. The patient's fluid balance is 500 mL over the past 24 hours, with a cumulative fluid deficit of 2 L.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral wheezing and rhonchi on auscultation. The patient's labs show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 12,000/Î¼L, hemoglobin (Hct) of 10 g/dL, and platelet count (Plt) of 150,000/Î¼L. The patient's creatinine (Cr) is 1.5 mg/dL, and troponin (TropT) is 0.5 ng/mL. The patient's blood glucose is 120 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show bilateral pleural effusions on chest X-ray. The patient's microbiology results are pending.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and respiratory support increase the risk of VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's underlying sepsis and antibiotic therapy may lead to septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and ongoing vasopressor therapy increase the risk of recurrent cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and fluid deficit increase the risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient's prolonged ICU stay and vasopressor therapy increase the risk of stress ulceration and bleeding.
6. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and prolonged ICU stay increase the risk of DVT.
7. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient's central lines and ongoing antibiotic therapy increase the risk of CLABSI.

The patient's assessment and plan include continued mechanical ventilation, antibiotics for MRSA pneumonia, and supportive care. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR).

5. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulcer due to his critical illness and the use of corticosteroids, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and other complications if not prophylactically treated.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but there are several potential medical complications that can arise if not recognized and treated promptly.

 ABDOMINAL PAIN (INCLUDING ABDOMINAL TENDERNESS)
 CONSTIPATION (OBSTIPATION, FOS)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   A 60 year old gentleman with HIV on HAART and new hypoxia, radiographic
   evidence of pneumonia, and influenza A.  This morning he is agitated
   with increasing O2 requirement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  No signs of PE on CT or DVT w/ [**Name (NI) 3667**]
   Unclear why patient has an increased oxygen requirement this morning
   and we are unable to wean him from the vent.  He did not do well with
   diuresis and he is not very fluid up on this admission. CT chest w/
   ground glass and not effusions.  Wonder if this is his problem is
   parenchymal vs pulmonary vasculature\
   - run even for volumes.
   - f/u repeat blood and sputum cultures. Only (+) for yeast at this
   point.
   - Completed 8/10 days of Vanc and Ceftriaxone.  CT chest shows PNA
   still present.
   - Oseltamivir 150mg PO BID.  Today is day 7.  Will continue for 10 day
   course.
   - try to wean PEEP to see if he is PEEP-responsive suggesting a
   parenchymal or mechanical cause of his resp distress
   - if PEEP unable to be weaned, drop esophageal balloon to measure
   pressures because may be higher than assume based on CXR and exam
   - [**Name (NI) 3667**] to look for DVT and call radiology to see if there are PE
s on
   imaging even though it is not a CTA
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Patient again says that he has abdominal pain and he
   is agitated this morning.  His abdominal U/S showed no biliary duct
   obstruction and KUB had no evidence of obstruction.  He is now
   stooling, but given that he is getting a CT scan of his lungs we will
   expand to a CT torso. No cause of abdominal pain seen on CT scan.
   - Given elevated lipases, is on Fentanyl/Versed instead of propofol;
   lipase trending towards normal now
   - Continue BM regimen, but less aggressive
   - Continue to monitor, seems to have stabilized
   .
   # Metabolic Alkalosis: would appear that has metabolic acidosis that is
   compensated, but since on vent could be that had resp acidosis w/
   metabolic compensation and has started to hyperventilate acutely.  An
   acute resp alkalosis on a compensated resp acidosis.
   - Treat resp distress
   .
   # Agitation: has a significant component of anxiety contributing to
   respiratory alkalosis and agitation when weaned.  Did well with
   seroquel, can uptitrate.
   patient is difficult to adequately sedate with fentanyl/versed but had
   previously been relatively calm.  Unclear whether he has a new process
   going on or has new delirium.
   - continue with fent/versed for now.
   - add seroquel to see if can wean sedation
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: on admission, Cr has now normalized.
   - Trend Cr
   - Foley catheter to monitor UOP
    .
   4) Anemia: The patient's Hct is lower than baseline without recent
   evidence of bleeding.  His MCV is 80, concern for iron deficiency
   anemia.  Hemolysis unlikely but not impossible.
   - Iron studies more consistent with chronic disease but not classic
   - Haptoglobin normal so less likely to be hemolysis
   - Type and screen
   - Trend Hct's
   .
   5) HIV: Patient's HIV currently well controlled although not on HAART
   at this time due to illness.
   - restarted HAART, home regimen
   .
   6) DM2: Blood sugars appear well controlled
   - Q6 ISS, no standing insulin
   .
   7) Hyperlipidemia:  Hold Atorvastatin while sorting out liver
   dysfunction.
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds- replete w/ fiber at 80
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
   Access: Peripherals 20g x2. [**Month (only) 51**] need PICC in future. Place A-line
   today.
   Code:  Full (discussed with patient)
   Communication: Patient & sister [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11689**]
   Disposition: Pending clinical improvement/extubation
